title: La Flèche Wallonne: Routes, how to watch, teams and everything you need to know
content:
Cyclist
La Flèche Wallonne: Routes, how to watch, teams and everything you need to know

La Flèche Wallonne on Wednesday 19th April marks the halfway point of cycling’s Ardennes week, flanked by the Amstel Gold Race and Liège-Bastogne-Liège. It’s all about one thing: the famous Mur de Huy. Translated to ‘the Wall of Huy’, its position towards the end of the race deals a knockout blow to anyone suffering before its 9.6% average, and brutal 26% max gradient.

Like many cycling races, La Flèche Wallonne was first run to boost sales of the newspaper Les Sports in 1936. The men’s race became part of the WorldTour in 2009 with the women’s race created in 1998 and moved to WorldTour status in 2016. Anna van der Breggen’s dominancy in La Flèche Wallonne with seven victories helped earn her the nickname ‘Queen of the Ardennes’, while retired-road-now-active-gravel-rider Alejandro Valverde holds the title for most wins in the men’s peloton with five.

In 2022, Dylan Teuns (then Bahrain Victorious) held off Valverde on the final of three ascents of the Mur de Huy for victory in the men’s race, while Marta Cavalli (FDJ-Suez) tracked down and passed Movistar’s legendary Annemiek van Vleuten to win the women’s. Both champions should be taking to the start line on Wednesday, with Teuns now racing for Israel-Premier Tech and Cavalli recently making her return to racing at Brabantse Pijl after taking time away from racing to fully recover from a violent crash during the 2022 Tour de France Femmes.

  • Read more: Mur de Huy classic climb

La Flèche Wallonne 2023: Key information

  • Date: Wednesday 19th April 2023
  • Start: Women’s – Huy; Men’s – Herve
  • Finish: Huy
  • Distance: Women’s – 131.5km; Men’s – 194.2km
  • Live TV coverage: GCN+, Eurosport 2, discovery+
  • 2022 winners: Marta Cavalli (FDJ-Nouvelle Aquitane-Futuroscope), Dylan Teuns (Bahrain Victorious)
  • Most wins: Anna van der Breggen (seven), Alejandro Valverde (five)

La Flèche Wallonne 2023: Routes and profiles

Women’s parcours

The women’s race will once again begin in Huy for a total of 131.5km. After 52km of racing, the peloton will enter a circuit featuring three climbs: the Mur de Huy (1.3km, 9.6%), Côte d’Ereffe (2.1km, 5%) and Côte de Cherave (1.3km, 8.1%).

Since 2022, the women’s peloton has scaled the Mur de Huy three times, matching the number of ascents undertaken by the men’s peloton. It’s on the third time that the race will conclude, and here that Cavalli powered away from a struggling Van Vleuten to win the last edition.

Men’s parcours

Beginning just east of Liège in Belgium, the men’s peloton will once again depart from Herve, just as in 2020. The start line has changed many times over the years, jumping from nearby towns such as Seraing, Ans, Charleroy and Blegny.

The men’s route for the 2023 La Flèche Wallonne is relatively unchanged from the previous edition won by Dylan Teuns, albeit just under 8km shorter. Towards the finish, riders will tackle three laps of a circuit which, like the women’s peloton, features the three climbs of the Côte d’Ereffe (2.1km, 5%), Côte de Cherave (1.3km, 8.1%) and Mur de Huy (1.3km, 9.6%).

La Flèche Wallonne 2023: How to watch on TV and streaming

In the UK, Europe and select international territories, both the men’s and women’s La Flèche Wallonne races will be broadcast and live-streamed on Eurosport, GCN+ and Discovery+, with the full race available to watch back afterwards on GCN+ and highlights on YouTube via GCN Racing and Eurosport.

UK pricing for a GCN+ subscription is £6.99 a month or £39.99 per year. GCN+ is ad-free, gives commentary choices and provides cycling-based documentaries to watch. The Entertainment & Sports pass Discovery+ subscription costs £6.99 a month or £59.99 a year, if you like your pro racing with a side order of Dr Pimple Popper and Expedition Bigfoot.

In the USA and Canada, you can catch the action on Flobikes; coverage of the men’s and women’s race in New Zealand will be on Sky; and to watch in Australia both men’s and women’s races will be on SBS.

Live TV and streaming times

All times BST and subject to change by broadcasters.

Women’s Flèche Wallonne

  • Eurosport 2: 10:55 – 12:30
  • GCN+: 09:55 – 11:35

Men’s Flèche Wallonne

  • Eurosport 2: 14:30 – 17:00
  • GCN+: 12:00 – 16:00

La Flèche Wallonne: Previous ten winners

2022: Dylan Teuns; Marta Cavalli
2021: Julian Alaphilippe; Anna van der Breggen
2020: Marc Hirschi; Anna van der Breggen
2019: Julian Alaphilippe; Anna van der Breggen
2018: Julian Alaphilippe; Anna van der Breggen
2017: Alejandro Valverde; Anna van der Breggen
2016: Alejandro Valverde; Anna van der Breggen
2015: Alejandro Valverde; Anna van der Breggen
2014: Alejandro Valverde; Pauline Ferrand-Prévot
2013: Daniel Moreno; Marianne Vos
